guide.introduction: You will need the Rovera 4WD robot kit from the Maker Shed before proceeding.
guide.introduction_rendered: You will need the Rovera 4WD robot kit from the Maker Shed before proceeding.

lines.text: The book Make an Arduino-Controlled Robot, which is included in the kit, contains many helpful graphics and drawings, while this Make Project will only include assembly photos. The book is especially useful for the wiring diagrams and exploded views.
lines.text_raw: The book ''Make an Arduino-Controlled Robot'', which is included in the kit, contains many helpful graphics and drawings, while this Make Project will only include assembly photos. The book is especially useful for the wiring diagrams and exploded views.

lines.text: I will be referring to the book in certain spots, and will include specific page/figure references where I can.
lines.text_raw: I will be referring to the book in certain spots, and will include specific page/figure references where I can.

lines.text: First, solder together your Motor Shield and mount it on your Arduino Leonardo. Instructions for assembling the Motor Shield can be found here.
lines.text_raw: First, solder together your Motor Shield and mount it on your Arduino Leonardo. Instructions for assembling the Motor Shield can be found [guide|2525|here].

lines.text: The first subassembly we're going to put together is the Ping Sensor mount. All required parts can be found with the sensor itself in a small plastic bag. Open it up and take all the parts out now.
lines.text_raw: The first subassembly we're going to put together is the Ping Sensor mount. All required parts can be found with the sensor itself in a small plastic bag. Open it up and take all the parts out now.

lines.text: The first step is to enlarge two of the holes in the servo horn, so we can fasten it to the aluminum sensor mount. Remove the horn from the servo with a small phillips-head screwdriver. Drill through the second hole on two of the horn arms with a 3/32" bit, as seen in the photo.
lines.text_raw: The first step is to enlarge two of the holes in the servo horn, so we can fasten it to the aluminum sensor mount. Remove the horn from the servo with a small phillips-head screwdriver. Drill through the second hole on two of the horn arms with a 3/32" bit, as seen in the photo.

lines.text: If you don't have a 3/32" drill bit, you can also use a knife to enlarge the hole.
lines.text_raw: If you don't have a 3/32" drill bit, you can also use a knife to enlarge the hole.

lines.text: Now insert the circular rubber piece into the hole of the Aluminum sensor mount. This will protect the sensor cable from harm.
lines.text_raw: Now insert the circular rubber piece into the hole of the Aluminum sensor mount. This will protect the sensor cable from harm.

lines.text: Now grab the two smallest screws and matching nuts from the pile of parts and fasten the servo horn to the Aluminum sensor mount.
lines.text_raw: Now grab the two smallest screws and matching nuts from the pile of parts and fasten the servo horn to the Aluminum sensor mount.

lines.text: Make sure the circular protrusion from the horn faces away from the mount, so you can attach it to the servo motor again.
lines.text_raw: Make sure the circular protrusion from the horn faces away from the mount, so you can attach it to the servo motor again.

lines.text: Once the horn and mount are attached, put the assembly back on the servo and replace the black screw to hold everything in place.
lines.text_raw: Once the horn and mount are attached, put the assembly back on the servo and replace the black screw to hold everything in place.

lines.text: The servo doesn't have continuous rotation capabilities, so it's likely that the mount isn't properly centered. Wiggle the Al mount back and forth and adjust the position of the horn on the servo to make sure the mount faces forward when the servo is rotated half-way around.
lines.text_raw: The servo doesn't have continuous rotation capabilities, so it's likely that the mount isn't properly centered. Wiggle the Al mount back and forth and adjust the position of the horn on the servo to make sure the mount faces forward when the servo is rotated half-way around.

lines.text: Next, grab the Parallax Ping sensor and mount it to the Aluminum sensor mount with two nuts, bolts, and plastic spacers. Then grab the cable and plug it into the sensor, ensuring that the black wire lines up with the Ground pin on the sensor.
lines.text_raw: Next, grab the Parallax Ping sensor and mount it to the Aluminum sensor mount with two nuts, bolts, and plastic spacers. Then grab the cable and plug it into the sensor, ensuring that the black wire lines up with the Ground pin on the sensor.

lines.text: Now grab one of the two larger side pieces and prepare to attach the motors. You'll need two 25mm bolts, two lock washers, two normal washers, and two nuts for each motor.
lines.text_raw: Now grab one of the two larger side pieces and prepare to attach the motors. You'll need two 25mm bolts, two lock washers, two normal washers, and two nuts for each motor.

lines.text: Insert both bolts through the long metal piece and the motor itself before sliding the normal washer and lock washer on top, in that order. Then tighten it all down with the two nuts.
lines.text_raw: Insert both bolts through the long metal piece and the motor itself before sliding the normal washer and lock washer on top, in that order. Then tighten it all down with the two nuts.

lines.text: You'll need to repeat this three more times until you have two long metal pieces, each with two motors attached.
lines.text_raw: You'll need to repeat this three more times until you have two long metal pieces, each with two motors attached.

lines.text: Now grab one of the short side pieces and the red power switch. First, thread one of the thin & wide M6 nuts onto the shaft of the switch. Then, slide the star-shaped lock washer on top, and insert the switch into the bent metal plate. Now add the second M6 nut and tighten it all together!
lines.text_raw: Now grab one of the short side pieces and the red power switch. First, thread one of the thin & wide M6 nuts onto the shaft of the switch. Then, slide the star-shaped lock washer on top, and insert the switch into the bent metal plate. Now add the second M6 nut and tighten it all together!

lines.text: We'll accomplish a similar task with the charging jack, only with one less nut. Refer to Figure 3-13 on page 30 of Make an Arduino-Controlled Robot for details.
lines.text_raw: We'll accomplish a similar task with the charging jack, only with one less nut. Refer to Figure 3-13 on page 30 of ''Make an Arduino-Controlled Robot'' for details.

lines.text: Next, grab the 5xAA battery holder and fasten it to the base plate with two M3 countersunk bolts (the only two countersunk bolts in the hardware bag).
lines.text_raw: Next, grab the 5xAA battery holder and fasten it to the base plate with two M3 countersunk bolts (the only two countersunk bolts in the hardware bag).

lines.text: Next, grab four 0.1uF capacitors and connect them between the leads on each motor. I prefer to slide the leads through the terminal holes.
lines.text_raw: Next, grab four 0.1uF capacitors and connect them between the leads on each motor. I prefer to slide the leads through the terminal holes.

lines.text: But, before you solder those caps on, cut four pieces of wire, each roughly three inches long. Spread the red and black leads apart and strip 3/16" off the end of each. Attach them to the motor terminals as well and solder, taking care not to melt the plastic casing of the motor.
lines.text_raw: But, before you solder those caps on, cut four pieces of wire, each roughly three inches long. Spread the red and black leads apart and strip 3/16" off the end of each. Attach them to the motor terminals as well and solder, taking care not to melt the plastic casing of the motor.

lines.text: Now you have a choice. If you'd like to eventually trickle-charge your robot, solder up the circuit according to the first photo. If you wouldn't like to trickle-charge in the future, solder up the simpler power circuit, shown in the third photo.
lines.text_raw: Now you have a choice. If you'd like to eventually trickle-charge your robot, solder up the circuit according to the first photo. If you wouldn't like to trickle-charge in the future, solder up the simpler power circuit, shown in the third photo.

lines.text: I chose the trickle-charging circuit. The second photo shows the setup - take care not to short anything out on the metal frame or another component.
lines.text_raw: I chose the trickle-charging circuit. The second photo shows the setup - take care not to short anything out on the metal frame or another component.

lines.text: If you have any heatshrink tubing lying around, use it here. If you don't have any, no worries - just make sure nothing's getting shorted on the frame.
lines.text_raw: If you have any heatshrink tubing lying around, use it here. If you don't have any, no worries - just make sure nothing's getting shorted on the frame.
